I posted the following in <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk>, but someone mentioned this channel, so I'll just paste it below:

I coded up 3 solutions to Day 15 of Advent of Code (spoilers), and got the following timings:
<https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15-unsafe-vector.rkt|Racket w/ unsafe vector/arithmetic> => 0.68 seconds
<https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15.c|C version> => 0.47 seconds
<https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15.jl|Julia w/ mutable vector> => 0.41 seconds
I was impressed that Julia was faster than C. On the one hand, I haven't coded C seriously since 1996, but on the other, I'm very much a Julia newbie.

I'm just curious if an experienced Julia coder can spot any obvious inefficiencies in the <https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15.jl|little Julia program> - even though it came in faster than C, that doesn't mean I wouldn't like it to be faster :slightly_smiling_face:

So, I'm looking at the Julia  <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/29841|#29841>, where I learned that `HTML` and `Text` are errors and would be removed from Julia 2.0.   So, I've been looking to replace them with local code as advised (since <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/38892|pull #38892> was denied).   Here is the code in question.
```mutable struct Text{T}
    content::T
end

Base.print(io::IO, t::Text) = print(io, t.content)
Base.print(io::IO, t::Text{<:Function}) = t.content(io)
Base.show(io::IO, t::Text) = print(io, t)```
When I do a straight-up replacement, calling this type `Reprint` (let's say), it seems to work.  At first I thought it was slower; but I think that's a sampling error on an imperfect laptop.  I have a question.

1. When I drop "mutable" things get slower, almost 40% slower.
2. If I replace `content::T` with `content::Function` things also get much slower.
I'm using this in a `Text() do io ... end` style, so I was seeing if it could be improved or simplified.  I guess not?  What are the impacts of using `{T}`?

Are there usually issues with type inference when shadowing local variables? Consider this relatively nonsensical example:
```module Stuff
function solve_b(filename)
    your = Vector{Int}()
    _nearby = Vector{Vector{Int}}()
    ruledict = Dict{String, Vector{UnitRange}}()
    nearby = filter(true, _nearby)
    Dict(
        rulename => Set(filter(_ -> all(true, nearby), 1:length(your)))
        for rulename in ruledict
    )
end
end```
There are no issues when you run `@code_warntype Stuff.solve_b("a")`, but if `_nearby` is changed to `nearby`, then it infers `nearby@_6::Core.Box` and `nearby@_8::Union{}` instead of `Vector{Vector{Int64}}` as it's supposed to.

I wrote a simple function to sum integers from 1 to n as a simple test of BigInt:
```function sum_n(n::BigInt)::BigInt
  val = BigInt(0)

  while n > 0
    val += n
    n -=  1
  end

  val
end
sum_n(BigInt(10))
@time println(sum_n(BigInt(6000000))) # 6 Million```
It takes roughly 2.2 seconds to sum 6M numbers. By comparison, the following Racket function can sum 1B numbers in about the same amount of time. The Julia code has 30M in allocations which seems crazy. Does the BigInt implementation allocate a new BigInt for each arithmetic operation?
```(define (sum-n n [result 0])
  (if (> n 0) 
      (sum-n (- n 1) (+ result n))
      result))

(time (sum-n 1000000000)) ; 1 Billion```

I have a function like this (what it does isn't really important):
```function stabilize(curr, tolerance, distance=maximum(size(curr)))
    prev = nothing
    while prev != curr
        prev = deepcopy(curr)
        for I in CartesianIndices(curr)
            prev[I] == 'L' && count_occupied(prev, I, distance) == 0         && (curr[I] = '#')
            prev[I] == '#' && count_occupied(prev, I, distance) >= tolerance && (curr[I] = 'L')
        end
    end
    count(==('#'), curr)
end```

```julia> @btime stabilize(......)
  13.499 ms (720 allocations: 4.00 MiB)```
Why is this the case?

Hello all, I'm trying to optimize the following code. Essentially, I'm want to find the minimum value from `value` for each unique combination of 2 vectors (for the purposes of this code, v1 = 1 and v2 = 2 is the same as v1 = 2 and v2 = 1, which is why I do that hacky part with `min` and `max`). I need to scale this up pretty massively, so I'm hoping to find ways to speed it up. Any suggestions? Thanks very much!!
```using Base.Threads
# Vector 1
v1 = rand(collect(1:1000), 100000)
# Vector 2
v2 = rand(collect(1:1000), 100000)
# Values
value = rand(100000)

# Get unique combos of v1 and v2
minv = min.(v1, v2)
maxv = max.(v1, v2)
unique_combos = unique(tuple.(minv, maxv))
n_unique = length(unique_combos)

# init a vector to house minimum of `value` per unique v1 and v2 combination
value_mins = Vector{Float64}(undef, n_unique)

# loop through to find minimum per unique group
@threads for i in 1:n_unique
    unique_combo = unique_combos[i]
    min_value_for_combo_i = minimum(value[(minv .== unique_combo[1]) .& (maxv .== unique_combo[2])])
    value_mins[i] = min_value_for_combo_i
end```

```function pairwise_analysis2(x::Array{Int16, 2})
    m, n = size(x)
    mean_matrix = Matrix{Float64}(undef, (n, n))
    @views @inbounds for i = 1:n
        for j = 1:n
            total::Int16 = 0
            for k = 1:m
                total += x[k, i] == x[k, j]
            end
            mean_matrix[i, j] = total / m
        end
    end
    return mean_matrix
end

X = Array{Int16}(rand(0:1, (1000, 1000)));
@btime pairwise_analysis(X)```

Hi all. I have a question about getting good performance out of threading. I don't have a really minimal example, but can point you to a repo with the code (~200 lines):

<https://github.com/vancleve/threading_example>

On my macbookpro, running the `@time evolve_replicates!(pop, rp)` from <https://github.com/vancleve/threading_example/blob/master/popsim.jl#L30>
I get something like (after running once to compile)
no threads  `3.936467 seconds (7.94 M allocations: 4.620 GiB, 14.60% gc time)`
1 thread      `3.890999 seconds (7.94 M allocations: 4.620 GiB, 16.57% gc time)`
2 threads    `2.340651 seconds (7.94 M allocations: 4.620 GiB, 25.03% gc time)`
4 threads    `1.786248 seconds (7.94 M allocations: 4.620 GiB, 41.74% gc time)`
8 threads    `1.658927 seconds (7.96 M allocations: 4.621 GiB, 58.21% gc time)`

Here are flame graphs for 1 thread (left) and 8 threads (right).

I know I have to reduce allocations, but was hoping to get some advice how best to do this since quite of a bit of the allocation time is coming in basic linear algebra stuff like matrix division and using `I` as identity matrix.

I've also thought about using `Distributed` but I ran into world age issues when passing functions to the workers...

Implemented a simple agent based SIR model in julia as it's been a long time since I've written anything agent based. Here is the main function, any low hanging fruit I am missing?
```function agents_step!(u_next,u,graph,params,t,rand_gen)
    @unpack p, recovery_rate  = params  
    u_next .= u
    for (v,agent) in enumerate(u)
        if agent == Susceptible
            for w in LightGraphs.neighbors(graph,v)
                if u[w] == Infected && rand(rand_gen) < p
                    u_next[v] = Infected
                end
            end
        elseif agent == Infected
            if rand(rand_gen) < recovery_rate
                u_next[v] = Recovered
            end
        end
    end
end```

So I currently am having a mini-contest between a co-worker of mine about performance.

He claims that Java is one of the fastest languages for his toy-problem.

I wrote a Julia version but my code currently runs at <2x the speed of his Java code.

Can anyone suggest to me some ways to increase my performance? Also feel free to give any un-solicited advice about my coding style :slightly_smiling_face:
Note this has to all follow the same structure (e.g. single threaded, must use recursion)

The toy problem is just <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peg_solitaire|peg solitaire> but on a triangular board. It involves lots and lots of array append and lots of recursion.

<https://github.com/ayman-albaz/peg-performance/blob/master/src/main/julia/performance.jl>

attachments.title: Peg solitaire
attachments.text:
Peg solitaire (or Solo Noble) is a board game for one player involving movement of pegs on a board with holes.  Some sets use marbles in a board with indentations. The game is known simply as Solitaire in the United Kingdom where the card games are called Patience.  It is also referred to as Brainvita (mainly in India, where sets are sold commercially under this name).
The first evidence of the game can be traced back to the court of Louis XIV, and the specific date of 1697, with an engraving made ten years later by Claude Auguste Berey of Anne de Rohan-Chabot, Princess of Soubise, with the puzzle by her side.  The August 1687 edition of the French literary magazine Mercure galant contains a description of the board, rules and sample problems.  This is the first known reference to the game in print.
The standard game fills the entire board with pegs except for the central hole. The objective is, making valid moves, to empty the entire board except for a solitary peg in the central hole.

```function Base.rand(rng::AbstractRNG, s::ZWDist)
    return ifelse(Base.rand(rng) < s., 0, Base.rand(rng,s.base_dist))

function Random.rand!(rng::AbstractRNG, s::ZWDist, l::T) where T<:AbstractVector
    Random.rand!(rng,l)

```function calc_dx_K(K, X, _squ, res)
    (d, n) = size(X)
    
    for dim=1:d
        res[:, :, dim] .= (-1/_squ * (X[dim, i] - X[dim, j]) * K[i, j] for i=1:n, j=1:n)
    end
    
    res
end```

    @inbounds for i=1:n, j=1:n, dim=1:d
        res[i, j, dim] = -1/_squ * (X[dim, i] - X[dim, j]) * K[i, j]
    end
    res
end```

I'm currently trying the following with `FastGaussQuadrature` . Might anyone have a suggestion for how to improve performance?
```function fastgq(f, a, b)
    nodes, weights = gausslegendre( 10000 );
    
    x = 0.5*((b .- a).*nodes .+ (b.+a))
    
    out = 0.5*(b.-a)*dot( weights, f.(x) )
    
    return(out)
end```
